newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portuguese railway workers set strike for Jan 31.
newsitem.headline: Portuguese railway workers set strike for Jan 31.

text.p: Portugal's railway workers plan to stage a one-day strike on January 31 to protest against the restructuring of loss-making state railway company CP-Caminhos de Ferro Portugueses, a union leader said on Tuesday.

"The strike is to protest against the restructuring plans, reduce excessive working hours and demand improved career structures," Jose Manuel Oliveira of the Federation of Portuguese Railway Workers' Unions told Reuters.
He said the strike, which threatened to disrupt trains nationwide, could be averted if progress was made in the coming days in talks with management to settle the unions' demands.
About 8,000 of Portugal's 14,000 railway workers, including some train drivers, belong to the Federation, Oliveira said.
He said many station workers were presently working 12-hour shifts even though regulations limited work days to eight hours.

The Socialist government said last month that the state railway would invest some 600 billion escudos ($3.7 billion) in a three-year restructuring plan under which it would be split into two and private firms allowed to run some operations.
From February, the CP will cease to exist. It will be replaced by an operating company for passenger and freight services and another for infrastructure.
